# **Negligence:** 

![][image1]

*(If not a general novel harm/ physical injury \- jump to special harms)*

In the present case, \[defendant\] may be liable to \[plaintiff\] under the tort of negligence. The legal requirements necessary for the plaintiff to establish an action in the tort of negligence are as follows: 

1) the existence of a duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff ("duty");  
2) the defendant must have breached this duty of care to the plaintiff ("breach"); and   
3) the defendant's breach must have caused the damage suffered by the plaintiff ("causation"); in addition, the resulting damage should not be too remote ("remoteness").

Each of these questions will be dealt with in turn. In Singapore, the framework for determining whether or  
not a duty of care exists is found in the framework that was laid down by the SGCA in *Spandeck*  
*Engineering (S) Pte Ltd v Defence Science & Technology Agency* (‚ÄúSpandeck‚Äù). The framework consists  
of a preliminary requirement of factual foreseeability of the damage suffered, which can be negatived or  
reinforced by policy considerations at the second stage.

| Fringe cases: |
| :---- |
| Facts before breach In Deutsche Bank AG v Chang Tse Wen, it was held that whether a DoC exists, must be judged by reference to the matrix of facts obtaining up to the time the duty is said to have been breached. |
| Relational Economic Losses  Is there a 3rd party relationship? Based on the facts of the case, ‚Ä¶ (Explain what the parties interest in the property is). (If there is destruction of property) Show that the property is of some possessory interest  Spandeck In NTUC Foodfare Co-operative Ltd v SIA Engineering Co Ltd, it was held that even in cases of relational economic losses, the applicable test for a duty of care is still Spandeck. Additionally, the court held that there is ‚Äúno compelling normative justification‚Äù for the courts to transpose the specific factors relied upon in the foreign authorities into the Spandeck test. |
| Exclusion of Liability Clauses In Hedley Byrne & Co, notwithstanding the advertiser‚Äôs bank‚Äôs potential reliance on the credit reference that Easipower‚Äôs bank produced, it was held that the Bank was not liable for the negligent misstatement because of the words ‚Äúwithout responsibility on our part‚Äù embedded in the statement itself. |

# **Duty of Care (General/ Personal Injury/ Reproductive Wrongs):**

Following Spandeck Engineering, to establish Duty of Care, it must be shown that:  
(a) Factual foreseeability was present;  
(b) Proximity was present; and  
(c) There are no policy considerations negating the establishment of a duty of care

*(Move on the FF in the general negligence \- then to any special case, if Occupier, just jump straight to occupier for full prewrite)*

| For established duty of care relationships e.g. doctors/lawyers (Shortcut skip DOC): At this stage, duty of care is present between \<tortfeasor\> & \<innocent party\> given that a doctor-patient/lawyer-client relationship are established types of relationship as there is a strong circumstantial proximity and a \<patient/client\> is a recognised class of persons to whom duty is owed |
| :---- |

\[Write this if you have time\] ü°™ The principle of incrementalism is applied to the first and second stage in the sense that the court will refer to decided cases in analogous cases to examine how the courts arrived at conclusion in establishing duty of duty of care (‚ÄúDOC‚Äù) in terms of proximity and policy. 

\[Write this if you have time\] ü°™ However, as held in *Spandeck*, when there is no factual precedent, which implies a novel situation, ‚Äúshould not preclude the court from extending liability when it is fair and just to do so, taking into account the relevant policy considerations against indeterminate liability against the tortfeasor.‚Äù

1. ## **Factual Foreseeability**

| Rule  | Application  |
| :---- | :---- |
| The threshold test of factual foreseeability is satisfied if the defendant could factually foresee that the plaintiff would suffer some sort of loss of damage if reasonable care was not taken (by the injurer)  when \[doing something\]  \*\*\*Give some reasons why do you think it is so.  \[Write this if you have time\] ü°™ In *Spandeck*, the SGCA acknowledged that for factual foreseeability, it is often almost fulfilled. However, despite the low bar to be satisfied, they held that it is still necessary as a threshold question to be satisfied before consideration of any duty of care arises.   | (If person of professional standing) In *Animal Concerns*, the threshold requirement of factual foreseeability was easily fulfilled as the respondent was a clerk of works supervising the backfill operation in a construction project for an animal shelter. Given this role to supervise a construction project, which it naturally came with risk of damage (due to heavy machinery used, for instance), it was factually foreseeable that if he does not take reasonable care in supervising this operation, the appellant will suffer some sort of loss or damage.  Likewise, in the present case, the defendant is a \[usually a person of professional standing\] and \[doing some form of work\]. Hence it was factually foreseeable that if the defendant did not take reasonable care in \[the role\], the plaintiff would suffer some sort of loss or damage.  |

   

* Foreseeable: It is submitted that \[harm\] was reasonably foreseeable by \[defendant\] because they would reasonably be able to foresee that \[harm\] would occur if they \[did/did not\] take reasonable care in \[doing what\]. (reasons below if applicable) *(continue below is its a novel case, skip to special case if not)*  
    
  \[Manufacturer\]  
* It is factually foreseeable that if the manufacturer did not take care in the preparation or manufacture of the product, the consumer will suffer injury  
    
  \[Occupier\]  
* The threshold question of factual foreseeability is readily met in the case of occupiers as it is clearly foreseeable that entrants would suffer injury if occupiers did not take reasonable care to eliminate danger.


  \[Road Users\]

* It is factually foreseeable that if \<\_\_\_\_\> does not take reasonable care in driving, other road users will suffer injury

  \[Pure economic loss (negligent misstatements)\]

* The plaintiff‚Äôs loss of \[insert loss\] can be directly attributed to the defendant‚Äôs \[insert misstatement\]. Hence, it was foreseeable that the plaintiff would suffer economic loss from acting upon the defendant‚Äôs negligent misstatement.

2. ## **Proximity**

Was there sufficient legal proximity between the defendant‚Äôs act and the plaintiff?

* The first stage of the *Spandeck* framework to ascertain the duty of care is proximity. There must be sufficient legal proximity between the claimant and the defendant for a duty of care to arise.   
* As held in *Ramesh v AXA Life Insurance*, what is required is a careful examination of the closeness of the relationship between the parties to determine if a duty of care properly arises on the facts

1) #### **Physical proximity (in the sense of space and time)**

* Per *Spandeck*, **physical proximity** refers to the nearness and closeness in the sense of space and time between the persons.  
* Presently, there is physical proximity as the \<Defendant\> and \<Plaintiff\> were near each other when the \<negligent act\> occurred.

2) #### **Circumstantial proximity (relationships such as employment relationship etc.)**

* Per *Spandeck*, **circumstantial proximity** refers to the overriding relationship between the parties.  
* In the case of *Anwar Patrick Adrian v Ng Chong & Hue LLC*, the court found that circumstantial proximity arose because of the nature of the client‚Äôs instructions to the attorney.  
* Presently, there is circumstantial proximity as \<Defendant\> and \<Plaintiff\> were \<describe relationship which is akin to a contractual rs\>. 


3) #### **Causal proximity (closeness of the causal connection between conduct and loss/ directness)**

* Per *Spandeck*, **causal proximity** refers to the causal connection between the course of conduct and the loss or injury sustained.  
* Presently, there is causal proximity as the \<Defendant\>‚Äôs \<negligent act\> led to the \<Plaintiff\>‚Äôs \<physical damage\>.  
    
4) **Voluntary assumption of risk to avoid or prevent injury and reliance upon it (Use carefully)**   
* Per *Spandeck*, the court will consider the **twin criteria** of **voluntary assumption of responsibility (‚ÄúVAR‚Äù)** and **reliance.**  
* In the case of Anwar Patrick, the court held that the fact that the attorney had voluntarily assumed responsibility to undertake the client‚Äôs instructions, and that the client had relied on him to do so supported the finding of sufficient proximity for a duty of care to arise.  
* (+ if its relating to advice/ professional service, \- if its physical/psychiatric harm) In Ramesh s/o Krishnan v AXA Life Insurance Singapore Pte Ltd it was held that the twin concepts of assumption of responsibility and reliance tend to be more useful for particular types of cases involving negligent advice or provision of professional services whereas it is less important in situations involving negligent acts by defendants causing physical harm or psychiatric injury to plaintiffs who were strangers at the relevant time.  
* In the present case, \[defendant\] had voluntarily assumed responsibility to undertake \[task\]. Furthermore, \[plaintiff\] had relied on him to do so. This will likely support the finding that there was sufficient proximity between the parties to impose a tortious duty of care.

5) **Conclusions**  
* (General) In *Man Mohan Singh* and *Ngiam Kong Seng*, the CoA did not regard the three facets and the twin concepts of voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance as strict requirements which had to be fulfilled in order to find a duty of care.  
* (-ve) \[3 prox doesn‚Äôt matter, VAR/RR fails\] In *Man Mohan Singh*, the three facets were irrelevant to the court‚Äôs decision with respect to the claim for the costs of fertility treatment. There was insufficient legal proximity between the parents of the deceased children and the negligent driver based on the absence of a voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance, regardless of the three facets of proximity. According to the CoA, the defendant could not be regarded as having assumed the broad duty of ensuring that the appellants would not be rendered childless by his negligent driving, and conversely, it could not be said that the appellants relied on him to assume that level of legal responsibility. It seemed that the absence of any assumption of responsibility by the negligent driver and reliance by the parents in respect of the costs of fertility treatment was determinative of the legal proximity issue in that case.  
* (-ve) (Psychiatric harm) \[VAR/RR doesn‚Äôt matter, 3 prox fails\]  In *Ngiam Kong Seng*, it was held that the absence of voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance was irrelevant to the issue of duty of care in a psychiatric harm case. Instead, the decision that a duty of care was not established was primarily due to the absence of the three facets of proximity.  
* (+ve) (Third party) In *Anwar Patrick Adrian v Ng Chong & Hue LLC*, the CoA held that there was a duty of care owed by the lawyer to third parties affiliated to the client premised upon the three facets of proximity and a modified version of assumption of responsibility, notwithstanding the fact that there was an absence of reliance by the plaintiffs.  
    
6) **Additional considerations**  
   \[Knowledge \+ Control\]   
   (in cases where liability to an indeterminate class is a concern: NTUC Foodfare v SIA Engineering)  
* In Anwar Patrick Adrian v Ng Chong & Hue LLC, the CoA held that it may be apt to consider two other proximity factors:  
- the knowledge of the parties in a transaction as to the other party‚Äôs vulnerable positions; and  
- the defendant‚Äôs control over the risk of harm to the plaintiff and the plaintiff‚Äôs corresponding   vulnerability.

* In the case of NTUC Foodfare v SIA Engineering, the court found an additional proximity factor of knowledge. In the case, the court held that the defendant knew that if he were negligent in carrying out his duties, there would be resulting harm on \[plaintiff\]. Similarly, in Anwar Patrick, the court found that the negligent attorney had ‚Äúknowledge of the state of affairs at play‚Äù because he knew that his services were retained to benefit the third-party plaintiffs, knew of the relationship between the plaintiffs and his client, and knew that his client did not want his sons (plaintiffs) to be liable for any debt. In the present case, \[defendant\] also knew that there would be \[harm\] caused to \[plaintiff\] if he had acted negligently. This is evident because of \[facts\]. Therefore, it is submitted that the proximity factor of knowledge is also applicable in this case.

  \[Contractual Liability\]

* In Go Dante Yap, it was held that contractual duties as agreed by parties may give rise to a corresponding duty of care. Presumably, it could prove circumstantial proximity between the parties. This was unless the parties had deliberately wished for their contractual agreements to exclusively govern their respective liabilities to prevent the tortious duty of care which would cut across and be inconsistent with the contractual structure.
